text: Bottle: &nbsp Rating #4200: &nbsp Pours black, thin deep brown head, sudsy, little lacing. &nbsp Noticeable alcohol on the nose. &nbsp Otherwise toasted coconut, strong graham cracker, dark chocolate, and Bourbon aromas. &nbsp Bourbon and vanilla aspects are not as strong with this as others. &nbsp However, this is big on the graham cracker aspect. &nbsp Very warming, and thankfully not too alcoholic on the tongue. &nbsp Assertive roastiness with dark/bakers chocolate and graham cracker. &nbsp Yeah, roastiness, toasted coconut, graham cracker, bakers chocolate, and alcohol notes dominate. &nbsp Not as sweet as others, or vanilla like. &nbsp Its not syrupy either. &nbsp Seems that the body and mouthfeel are full to moderate. &nbsp Finish has some charred wood and ash characteristics, along with the aformentioned. &nbsp This one is a decent barrel aged example, but it could use a little more body and some caramel/vanilla sweetness. &nbsp Very enjoyable otherwise. &nbsp Thanks Kevin for the bottle!

12 oz. bottle from alexsdad06- thanks again, Brad! 2011 vintage. Pours an opaque, deep, dark brown color with a small dark tan head that immediately settles into spots of film and lace and a small ring. The aroma is pretty hot, with notes of bourbon, charred oak, vanilla, caramel, toasted brown sugar, molasses, coconut, and dark fruits. Warms the nostrils. Flavor of charred oak, vanilla, toasted brown sugar, marshmallow, coconut, chocolate, and bourbon throughout. Definitely doesnt mask the ABV at any point. Medium-bodied, with mellow carbonation. Nice bourbon barrel imperial stout.

Thanks to randjuke for this gem. 2011 vintage poured into a brandy snifter:

Pours a pitch black ink. A dense, boozy finger of dark brown head swells up only to recede back to a neat collar. Sexy ass legs. Slow, fine beading hovers just below the cap. Beautiful.

Rich dark chocolate, molasses, big bourbon, various cocoa, more big spicy bourbon, think BCBS. I could sit and snort at this all day.

Hot damn. Thick wood (hehe) notes, vanilla, bourbon, breakfast syrup, boozy finish. I feel like the vanilla might really pop with some age. Unfortunately, this is my one and only bottle but Im very grateful to have had the chance to try it!

Just another example of why the midwest conquers every other corner of the world when it comes to imperial stouts.

This bottle was courtesy of Lukafer, who gave it to me just to spread the love. Thanks Luke!

This beer pours a full bodied, black chocolate black with no head but a dark khaki lacing around the rim. The nose is very rich and roasty. T has some fudge brownie to it, LOADS of chocolate. That said, there isnt much bourbon at all. The flavors are really smooth and chocolaty. Again, loads of chocolate fudge and brownie. There is barely any bourbon at all and moderate roast. Great flavor on the chocolate standpoint, but disappointing in terms of barrel aged imperial stouts. This is the most palatable chocolate Ive ever experienced in a beer. It is pretty light in body, compared to others of the style. I would describe it as a light medium. It does however increase drinkability. Overall this is a very nice beer, but doesnt show the bourbon you would expect. If I had to guess, I would say that this is oak aged or just aged regular Plead the 5th. All of that said, this beer was delicious.

Bottle shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike.

The beer is near black with a thin, beige cap. The aroma offers bourbon and roast, followed by alcohol, vanilla, oak, chocolate. Great flavor, with prominent bourbon throughout. Additional tastes of vanilla and chocolates. Moderately low carbonation, with a smooth, buttery feel. A bit of heat in the finish, but 14% abv feels pretty nice. Overall, very enjoyable. A top notch barrel-aged imperial stout.

Great appearance and inviting chocolate aroma leads to a balanced taste, strong on bourbon, and satisfying mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle from fear025, thanks a ton. Pours black with a small, creamy, dense, tan head that quickly fades to a ring. Aroma is big bourbon/oak up front with semi-sweet chocolate, coffee and black malt. Flavor is rich chocolate, boozy bourbon, bitter roast and vanilla oak. Full body with a soft, creamy mouth feel. This is a fantastic beer, the barrel aging is executed perfect IMO.

Pours black with no head. The beer coats the glass as you swirl it. The aroma is full of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, roast malt and a bit of coffee. The flavor has all of these in various amounts. This beer is best a little warm. I had this on the sidewalk at Hawthornes during Philly Beer Week.
Pours black with no head, literally sticks to the inside of glass.  Huge aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and oak.  Taste is chocolate and bourbon.  Finish is roasted and sticky.

black, tan head reduces to ring. Nose is dark roast with hints of chocolate, prune, very dark and burnt. Flavor shows more roast and fruit, light chocolate and considerable oak, bit of lactic tartness through finish, milk and lemon contrasting roast. Thick, chalky.

Aroma of caramel, roast chocolate, vanilla, and molasses.  Pours black with a small brown film.  Taste is intensely sweet with great notes of chocolate and vanilla up front and a nice roasty devils cake finish.  This is a great dessert.

12oz bottle from sarro. Black with pretty much no head - just a tinge of brown around the rim. Bourbon, vanilla and oak is at the forefront but luckily with a bit of time to breath it does not overwhelm; nice roasted and sweet malts, some chocolate, bit of smoke. Full body, moderate carbonation, still hot with an initial burn but settles reasonably quickly to reveal a nice sweetness, a long finish with some bitterness, bourbon and vanilla just keep on giving. Quite tasty.

75cl bottle, thanks ygtbsm94.  Headless black body with brown edge.  Aroma is moderately sweet Bourbon, some vanilla, light raisin.  Taste is moderately sweet, Bourbon, some caramel, plum, light raisin.  Sticky medium-full body.

Bottle from Beerman6686.  Thanks!  2011 vintage.  Pours black with a thin tan foam on top that sheds spotty lacing.  Strong whiffs of chocolate and bourbon invade the senses upon cracking the bottle.  Theres also quite a bit of black licorice here too.  Mocha, ash, wood, and a touch of molasses round out the scent.  The aroma certainly shows some alcohol too.  Pretty good depth.  The flavor is equally as impressive, but showing some different things.  An ashy charcoal mixes with caramel, strong mocha, and of course, bourbon to provide the meat of the flavor.  Notes of damp wood too coming from the barrel with a bit of vanilla as well.  Its silky in the body and smooth going down.  The alcohol noted in the aroma is more subtle than I was expecting.  A soothing sipper for sure.  Surprisingly, I dont really pick up much black licorice, as noted so heavily in the aroma.  The bottom line is this is clearly a high quality barrel-aged Imperial Stout.

Bottle in celebration of Radiohead.  A great gift from Damico.  Pours a black color with a soapy caramel colored head.  Heavy alcohol, vanilla, and oak.  Some chocolate and caramel notes.  Sweet vanilla taste with that oak bite and creamy chocolate finish.  Wow. What a beer.

Draft at Baker Street for the Dark Horse Brewing Co. dinner...paired with a fantastic raspberry and caramel infused brownie.  Pours pitch black, very little light seeping through on the edges...nose is just ridiculous...notes of vanilla bean, candied fruits, bourbon, heavily roasted malts, some chocolate and more.  Slick, oily palate...flavors follow suite for the most part, a bit of licorice coming through on the back-end...alcohol well-hidden.  Fantastic stuff!!

Big thanks to GT2 for bringing this. Pours black with a tiny espresso brown head. Aroma is chocolate, dark sweet fruits, vanilla, bourbony notes, earthy roasted notes, weak medicine, rather burnt, sugary sweetness and some fainted smoke. Taste is bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, dark dried fruits, dry wood, oatmeal, weak meaty, salty, burnt malts and some smoke. I like thiz!

12 oz bottle courtesy of GT2 - big thanks! Pours deep black with a small light brown head. Aroma is very bourbon forward, lots of wood and vanilla, lots and lots of chocolate, chocolate ganache, a hint of coffee and dark fruit, brown sugar, some dark berries, like blackberries - very pleasant and balanced aroma. Taste has a lot of the base beer with all its chocolate and brownie sweetness, and all the hard roastiness and bitter espresso notes, and the some dry oaky bourbon and vanilla notes. A nice berry quality as it warms. Sort of a salty component which compliments the sweetness and bourbon notes very well. Very different from a lot of other BA imperial stouts, and I like the saltiness. Good fucken stuff!!

Bottle thanks, GT2! pours pitch black, with a  small beige head. Aroma:  vanilla, oak, woody, bourbon, roasted, heaps of dried fruits,  chocolate, sweet fruity, raisins, figs, plums, savory,  dusty, milk chocolate, sweet liquorice,  butterscotch, caramel, burnt sugar. Taste:  thick and smooth, a bit tingly, you really get the bourbon, vanilla, silky, sweet liquorice, rich,  dry chocolate, roasted, matroshatte, slight sugarburn, grassy, tobacco,  some roasted bitterness, salty notes, savory, sweet and dry endnotes
Bottle courtesy of GT2, thanks!  Completely black, small dark brown head. Aroma of liquorice, chocolate, coffee. Tasteis mildly boozy dark bitter cocoa, burnt coffee, vanilla.  Very nice.

This poured a jet black color with a very small dark tan head.  Aroma was dark roasted malts, inviting dark and sweet chocolates, vanilla, some smores, and bourbon.  Flavor was much the same as the aroma, only way more intense.  This one is certainly up there for the best examples of how ba something the right way can make an already great  beer into a masterpiece, so well balanced in flavor and hardly any alcohol burn. Amazing stuff really.

shared by some nice fellow in line at DLD.  thanks!     bourbon addition worked quite well with this beer.   body held up nicely.    big, potent rich dark chocolate and chocolate mouse with some dry leather smoked out bourbon and vanilla.    rich, heartwarming.   pretty solid.   better than expected.

on tap at dark horse brewery...made a weekend trip up for a getaway and after looking on their website, was surprised to see Pt5 on tap.  waitress brings over a snifter and after a couple sips, I wonder...walk over to the bar and, yep, its the bb version!   pours black with a solid deep tan head leaving considerable lacing.  flavor is extraordinary...bourbon is meshing near perfectly here with a nice dose of vanilla as well...scrumptious!  aroma is chocolate, some rich fruits in the background, vanilla and roasted malt.  palate is oily and smooth and lasts very nicely without being overly thick.  what a treat...as this is one of the best bb stouts Ive had.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 This one is just fucking fantastic. As if the non BA version wasnt good enough, I think this one was def elevated.

Bottle vintage 2011 has a super dark brown bordering on black color with a thin coating of brown head. Aroma has sweet bourbon, oak, vanilla, rich malt, chocolate, and some roast. Nice and rich in a velvety sort of way. Mouth feel is hefty and coats well with low side carbonation. Flavor is bold and malty, some burn up front, bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolate, medium roast, and a bit of bitterness. Once this opens up and the heat burns off it is just fantastic. The beer itself is a big stout but the barrel level is just right to take this to another level.

Bottle from arkurzynski (thanks). Pours oily black brown with a tiny wispy tan film that leaves a thin collar. Aroma is vanilla dark fruit and bitter chocolate with a smooth scent of bourbon. Taste has strong vanilla and bourbon with  bitter chocolate and roasted malt and a little licorice that finishes very warming. Palate is full oily and slick with a drying warming finish. Really nice brew.

Medium sised tan head with fair retention and some spotty lace. black/brown edged color. Nose is nice with mellow whisky and roast notes, little coffee and chocolate with a little huskyness . Full bodied and a bit chewy, soft carbonation, little oily, dry on the palate. Tastey well balanced blend of roast, whisky, light cherry notes, bourbon and wood showing as it warms. Fairly dry long finish, lasting and warm. Solid BA Impy. Stout. Props to Robert @stateline for sharing this one.

12oz bottle from Mike. Pours near black with small dark tab head. Good looking beer. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit, chocolate, and roast. Amazing smelling beer. Flavors of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, roast, and nice warmth of the ABV, but not boozy in any way. Body is fine and carbonation is right. Really solid beer. Probably the best I have had from DH.

Pours a jet black with brown head. I love the base beer, and the BA not only suits it well, but was done correctly. I enjoyed this beer at a tasting this weekend and I think it is safe to say that when I heard someone mention (and I agreed) that it was on the level of BCBS that is pretty high praise.

2011 vintage bottle.  pours a rich dark brown, with a nice ring for head.  Aroma is rich with bourbon, malt, and vanilla.  The taste is top notch, with smooth bourbon taste with a clean finish.  One of the best BA beers out there.  Takes a great beer and makes it even better.

YES!  This is a bourbon barrel aged imperial stout.  Aroma was outrageous with loads of vanilla oak and roast.  The taste is lucious and amazingly rich and medium sweet with a dry roasty finish.  Want more.

Amazing pour on this, pours pitch black with a super fine head of deep mocha that screams $12 espresso, with fine lacing rarely seen in this style.  Nose is rich, roasted malt, hefty dark fudge, light bourbon thats super well integrated, vanilla.  Mouth is roasted, umami like body, not quite salty, not quite meaty, but somewhere in there, huge unsweetened dark fudge, tightly integrated bourbon that swells on the finish with some heat along with coffee beans and more unsweetened dark chocolate.  Feel is thin, really the big detractor here is the craftsmanship is great otherwise.
Awesome bourbon flavors, very close to hill farmstead Damon. Big corn notes and vanilla from the bourbon. The base beer handles this well. Awesome!

12oz Bottle. Thanks so much Sean for sharing the rarity. Big bourbon and roast umami nose. Lots of vanilla and the cherry-pit-like aspect I attribute to the oak barrel. I always enjoy it when it shows up in the aroma. Tight, creamy, and complex. Not really and rough edges. I think the barrel presence is a little strong, but it works in there pretty well. The snappy, bittersweet roast edge is really satisfying. I think this is up there just behind the best of the best of barrel-aged imperial stouts. I appreciate the lack of sweetness and dry, sharp finish. Warming.
Tasted the original next to this one. Tasty tasty tasty. Subtle wood and bourbon notes, thick beer

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2013 Date: March 14, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: mibirder Description: Opaque black with minimal head in the pour (slight light brown head formed when swirled) and spotty lacing. Aroma was roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Taste was roasty, cheap bourbon, bitter chocolate, some vanilla at start, woody/oak and dry chalky finish/after taste.  Smooth and medium to full bodied.  Thanks Sean!

September 2, 2013 - rerate as part of a blind tasting with BCS, KBS, Black Note and CW BBS.  Moved this up to a 9 in taste and 18 overall to get me at 4.4.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2012 2011 silver cap.  Pours a jet ink black with darker tan head.  Smell is the highlight.  Sweet vanilla cream, bourbon soaked oak, sweet rich toffee. With some lactose thickness.  Taste is still beautiful.  Rich dark chocolate milk with smooth vanilla bourbon.  Bitter but smooth. Faint dark fruits.  Thick and sloshy. Finish lovely but still a bit hot.

Pour from a bottle thanks to Kan. The color is ink black and opaque. Nice mocha head. Smell off the top is of roasted malt and coffee. Really smooth and rich on your palate. Flavors are complex of cocoa,toasted malt, coffee, bourbon, and oak. The beer is very well balanced without being a bourbon bomb. Also the beer finishes balanced and somewhat dry and no syrupy sweet characteristics. Really liked this beer.

(12oz bottle thanks to ericandersnavy) jet black pour with sparse soapy tan edge bubbles. Nose of fudge, bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate, quite rich. Taste of rich chocolate, fudge, alcohol, bourbon, vanilla, huge flavor, linger is huge and long.

Poured from 12oz bottle.  Pours nearly black with just a bit of tan head.  Aroma is some coffee and a touch of bourbon.  Tastes of coffee and bourbon.  I would have liked this to be a bit sweeter and maybe a little less bitterness.

Thanks to ramnuts 

A-Black appearance with a  dark tan head. 

S- Dark chocolate. Alcohol and some vanilla. 

T- Chalky, bitter chocolate.  Dry after taste. Not as much vanilla in the taste as there was in the aroma. 

M- Medium to thick. A tad thinner than I would have expected. 

O- Good ba stout. Nothing extrordinary. Lacks something, but cant really put my finger on it. Maybe a little more complexity would make this better.
A very nice Imperial Stout.  Comes out strong and swinging, but mellows with a few sips. An excellent Imperial Stout.

Bottle from Sean - thanks!  Black pour with a thin ring of expresso colored foam on the edge of the glass.  Aroma is smooth, lush bourbon with coconut, vanilla, marshmallow, perhaps a smidge of alcohol heat, chocolate, subtle roast, coffee, and a clean, dry finish.  Amazing aroma - absolutely on par with an a-grade barrel aged offering from Firestone Walker.  Taste is dominated by the bourbon from start to finish but there is some roast, chocolate, light coffee, and even some dark fruit notes to be sussed out.  The finish does present a bit of bitterness from the alcohol.  Mouthfeel is clean, even, and perhaps on the light side but not watery . . . more like soft and velvety.  Great beer.

2011 bottle, thanks to sarro, 03/02/2012.  Pours black, thinnest of dark tan heads, recedes to fine ring around the glass.  Awesome aroma, big bourbon with caramel toffee, vanilla, brown sugar, hint of fruitiness, chocolate brownies.  Taste has vanilla chocolate, liqueur-like sweetness balanced by roasted cocoa and espresso, finish of dark malts and smooth bourbon.  Full and almost creamy in the mouth, drinks easy for its strength.  Pretty great brew, definitely lives up to its reputation.

Bottle 2011.  Aroma has notes of bourbon, chocolate, espresso, dark dried fruits, molasses and wood tannins.  Just lovely.  Black hue with a small brown head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is very sweet and medium bitter.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a really nice Impy.  The bourbon is upfront but blends well and does allow the other flavors to come through.  Very nice.  This one surprised me.

Thanks to Mike for the bottle!  Poured into a Duck-Rabbit snifter.  Body is darker than dark with a thin  ring of milk chocolate foam on top.  Leaves a few patches of lacing behind.  Lots of sweet honey bourbon on the nose.  Vanilla, oak and chocolate rise up from the glass.  Smells like a bourbon soaked chocolate dessert.  The flavor is filled with fudge and honey bourbon.  Still has some nice roastiness like the base beer, but much sweeter from the barrel aging.  The body is slick and on the thicker side, but lacking in adequate carbonation.  Some booze throughout.  Overall, this is an excellent bourbon barrel stout.  Could use a few more bubbles and a bit more complexity, but definitely tasty.

Black in color with a nice viscosity and a finger of dense brown head.  Heavy on the bourbon and vanilla, as expected.  Great chocolate character with hints of roasted malt, caramel, and molasses.  Pleasantly sweet, but not cloying.  Great milk chocolate and vanilla flavors all the way through with tons of bourbon as well.  Not too heavy on the oak, but a little bit is present.  Mild roasted malt and caramel flavors.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2012 Trade from both Pantanap and Sean9689, thanks guys. Vintage 2011. Pours black with a medium brown head and beautiful lacings. Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, roasted malt, cocoa, very soft. Flavor is bourbon, dark chocolate, roasted malt, bitter coffee, dark caramel. Soft carbonation, creamy texture. Long finish. Very well balanced. This is amazing.

Bottle at a recent tasting...  Poured pitch black with a light tan head.  Chewy chocolate characters and vanilla with some malted roast, oak and bourbon.  Quite nice on the palate, smooth mouthfeel from the soft carbonation.

Deep black and opaque body. Two finger mocha colored head sits atop. The head recedes slowly. A substantial amount of lacing is left clinging to the walls of the glass. 

Bourbon aroma is very prominent. Sweet bourbon aroma, rather soft boozieness. Big chocolate and caramel aromas meld seamlessly with the bourbon. Moderate roast and vanilla noted. 

The flavor starts out bourbon heavy before a healthy dose of chocolate floods the palate. A rather assertive roasted malt flavor begins to emerge on the midpalate. The caramel flavor is much more subtle in the bottle version than on tap. Flavors are well integrates though not nearly as much as the tap version. A bit of heat on the back is noted but not obstructive. 

Full bodied Imperial Stout. The carbonation levels are low and appropriate. Very silky, soft texture. The finish is long and enjoyable.

Reviewed from a bottle this time to compare the the tapped version. Unfortunately I do not know the age of the keg, the tap version does seem slightly smoother. Very drinkable Imperial Stout. Despite the heat the alcohol is hidden rather well. Impressive beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 36cl, Vintage 2013, at 11%Vol, new exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex Stout, roasted/alcoholic and slightly sweet/spicy, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, small head, very good Winter brew, top class!, yet very expensive!

Sampled at EBF on Saturday afternoon. 
Pours a solid black with a decent tan head with some retention. Smell is heavy on the bourbon with lots of chocolate and roast, and some vanilla and wood. Taste is chocolate bourbon and roast. Thick body with a creamy smooth mouthfeel and a light level of carbonation. A big thick stout, one of my favorites of the day.

(12oz bottle, 2011 vintage, courtesy of ericandersnavy)  Pours an opaque black body with a spare brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, fudge, roasted malt, vanilla, bourbon, and caramel.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, light licorice, and caramel with a dry finish.
A Sim rate (Extreme Beer Festival, Boston): Great palate. Delicious dark chocolate but a bit too heavy on the bourbon.

This pours thick and extremely black with a thick brown mocha head. Bourbon, coffee, chocolate fudge, marshmallow, vanilla, tobacco, molasses and raisins on the nose. Vanilla, coffee, bourbon, chocolate fudge, tobacco, brown sugar, dried dark fruit and booze taste. Thick on the palate and a great long bourbon roasted finish.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2013 Pitch black pour into a snifter.  Nice thin mocha head.  Nose is chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, booze.  Taste is dead on with the nose with lots of vanilla, toffee, bourbon.  Non existent hop profile which is what you want in a true malt bomb like this.  Very little coffee bitterness as well which really works for me.  Very similar to Churchills Finest although a notch below.  Great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle many thanks to ICEatALAMO.  Pitch black pour, tan head.  Sweet milk chocolate, lots of vanilla, chocolate pudding, light bourbon barrel notes, and booze.  Tasty and silky mouthfeel, but not terribly complex.

Bottle sent my way be Ksurkin, thanks Ken!  Pours black with small sudsy tan head.  Nose is sweet bourbon nectar, dark chocolate, banana pudding, and an overall very nice balance between the heavy roast and bourbon like I have never seen in a bourbon aged stout.  Both the bourbon and the roast each have their time to shine while still melding together so excellently.   Its a little on the sweet and bourbon-y side in the flavor, but it ends bitter and roasty displaying the balance mentioned above. Tasty.

Shared by turdferguson. Pours inky black with one finger of dark chestnut brown head.  Nose is rich with dark chocolate and vanilla upfront with notes of wood and molasses and a light acidity.  Very rich and full flavor,  lots of vanilla and bourbon with charred wood and chocolate.  Hints of coffee and alcohol.  Full and viscous body with a good showing of alcohol.

Bottle pours oily black with minimal tan head.  Aroma bourbon with roast/malts.  Taste malts, cocoa, roast, bourbon.  Palate thick, not sticky or syrupy.  Finish nice balance between coca/hop bitterness and bourbon.  Alcohol very prominent with heavy alcohol burn.
Im not a huge fan of the regular Plead the 5th but the bourbon adds a new dimension and really balances out some of the bitterness.  Excellent beer.
Black body with no head. Smells of sweet malt and a little Bourbon. Tastes follows. Borubin and body mix well together.

12oz bottle pours an oily, opaque black with some cloudy tan head.  Nose is really awesome, vanilla, cola, cake, molasses, brown sugar, sorghum syrup, a little coffee, some nuts.  Flavor is sweet, vanilla, chocolate, coconut, malty, molasses, coffee with cream, Kahlua, lightly salty.  Medium bodied, sweet, super smooth finish.
Light black, big time bourbon aroma, lots of bourbon and vanilla taste, more sweet than I expected.  Wouldnt really want a lot, but really fantastic

12 oz bottle courtesy of Dak. Thanks. Pours an opaque jet black color with a small brown head that quickly dissipates to a fine ring. The aroma is big and bold with lots of dark fruits, black malts and a bit o whiskey. The flavor showcases raisins, dates, plums, burnt malts, well balanced bourbon, a trace of vanilla and some bitter dark chocolate. The palate is full and smooth with soft carbonation. The finish is long with lingering bourbon and chocolate. Overall: This really hit the spot. I loved it.

Bottle shared by a kind soul at STL big black beer bash.  Pour is pretty much black with a thin ring of brown foam.  Aroma is very smooth with hints of roasted malt, vanilla, brown sugar, and a touch of bourbon.  Flavor is also quite smooth with notes of toffee, smooth roasted malt, faint bourbon, and a nice vanilla note.  The best word to describe this one for me is smooth. Very cohesive and well-constructed.

Big thanks to Dougofthefuture for holding this great tasting!

Poured from a bomber into a snifter

A. Pours a dark charcoal color with a caramel head about 1mm thick. Settles as a nice foamy ring around the glass

S. Sweet chocolate dominating the smell, noticeable bourbon, caramel and light fruit

T. Sweet and sugary, but not overbearing at all. Very very malty, with dark chocolate and a slight toffee finish.

M. Medium body, coarse and dry finish

O. This is true a top shelf beer. Its sweet but not over done, very malty but not dominating the whole beer, the chocolate is at a good level, and a nice light coffee finish. This is a beer I will be looking to get more and more of. I suggest everyone try this!
2011 release...Just delicious, Nice vanilla caramel chocolate taste with a slight hint of bourbon but enough you know its there. Very smooth

355mL 2011 ed silver wax thanks to mikem409. Pours ink with a larger reddish mocha head settling abruptly to a bubbly layer. Nose is richer vanilla with thicker sweet bourbon. Very reminiscent of Goose Island Bourbon County Stout. Rich wood and mild dark cherries. Very inviting, dessert nose. Taste is silky, rich, spicy bourbon, big dark chocolate. Thankfully only hints of ash that sometimes plague Dark Horse beers. Bitter, thicker. Very enjoyable. Great palate. Lower carbonation with super rich, oily palate. Beautiful stuff. Underrated even in the Top 100. Should be Top 50. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Gigantic thanks to GT2 for this bottle! Pitch black pour, creamy light brown head. Nose holds beautiful vanilla bean, woody bourbon, rich creamy lactic sweetness, and some lovely roast character that, thankfully, fights through the barrel aged sweetness. Flavor is really beautiful; starts with beautiful milk chocolate and cacao, along with some great espresso bean. The finish is a delightful combination of molasses/vanilla wood sweetness and awesome creaminess at the end. Outrageously silky palate, low carbonation. Very very very nice.

Thanks GT2! Black pour with a sudsy tan head. Huge vanilla bourbon, caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, cocoa nib, and hints of booze lead to delicious barrel sweetness, finishing with cocoa nib and bakers chocolate like dryness. Thick rich palate with low carbonation. Excellent!

12oz bottle from my favorite MI trader.

Pours pitch black, just like the regular 5th with a small mocha head that recedes slowly to a thin collar with a little lacing.

Aroma is very sweet with lots of vanilla and dark chocolate with a solid bourbon presence.  There are some roasted malts in the nose but its definitely sweet with some molasses coming through, maybe hints of smoke and leather.  Gorgeous nose.

Taste is thick and chocolaty with heavily roasted black malts and licorice anchoring the backbone.  The vanilla is still there but more subtle than the nose and the wood from the barrel is more prominent in the finish.

The mouthfeel is wonderful, fullish and creamy, with the perfect amount of carbonation, just sticking to the palate after each sip.

The nose is more complex than the nose with the sweetness mixing with the barrel perfectly.  The taste isnt quite as nice but  its still excellent.  This is a nice example of what barrels can add to a beer.

A big thanks to Thorpe for letting me have some of this beer during our impromptu epic New Years Day tasting. 

Beer served in a sniffer. Beer is black, oily, this dark brown head of small bubbles, low retention, falls back to halo the glass minimal lacing and low carbonation. 

Aroma is sweet, chocolate, strong malt presence. The boubon come through strong. Mild oak. Smells like a big bourbon stout. 

Beer is medium to big in body, malty sweet with a strong bourbon character. Fudge and chocolate with minimal roast. The sweetness carries through all the way to the end. The bourbon wins in this beer. So sweet, so oaky, vanilla, booze but without heat. I really liked it.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle provided by TurdFurgison, thanks Eric! Poured into 3F wine glass.

A - Pours black, a fingers-worth of tan/mocha head, some good lacing and a thin cap on top which hangs around.

S - Peanut butter, tons of it. Like a Reeses Peanut Butter Cup. Sweet milk chocolate, light on the bourbon, oak, caramels, expresso. All very rich and decadent on the nose.

T - Reeses Peanut Butter Cups, chocolate, some dark fruit notes, oak, smooth bourbon character, coffee beans. I was really impressed how smooth and rich this was for 14%, very well-done. Bitter chocolate finish.

M - Full body, rich, thick, and creamy finish.

D - I never did get to try this on-tap, but I was very impressed with this out of the bottle. Def a top-notch -bal, no doubt about it. Still cant get over how easy this was to drink for 14%. Recommend.

Notes from a tasting held in April 2011. Thanks to Eric.
Aroma: bourbon, vanilla, dark stone fruits, roasted malts
Taste: roasted malts, vanilla, marshmallow
Overall: An amazing beer, rich and complex.

Huge thanks to mikem409, Merry Christmas!  Thick midnight pour with thin beige head.  Big roast and cocoa with mostly toasted coconut bourbon nose.  Roasted and patent malt, toasted coconut, bourbon, cocoa/semi-sweet chocolate, and some wood.  Very smooth bourbon character.  Feels surprisingly thin on the palate, but I think this is more due to the smooth flavor combination.  Very little booze.  Residual roasted malt/coffee and some bourbon.  A little heat.  Highly roast balanced just like the non-aged version.
Bottle thanks to bulldogp04. Pours rich black with dirt brown head. Nose/taste of rich chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and oak. Very smooth and rich thick mouth feel.

Bottle pour from Dalzale, thanks Greg!  Pour is a dark brown with very little head or lacing. Aroma is very booze forward, some roast, some chocolate, not a ton else.  Taste on the other hand, is very complex, decadent even.  Lots of sweet chocolate powder, caramel, vanilla, a touch of brown sugar.  Fairly sweet. Nice beer

12 oz. silver wax dipped bottle, 2011 vintage.  Dense, viscous, and fudgy looking, the nearly black body is almost impenetrable by light.  This is the darkest beer Ive seen in some time.  An initially moderate head of light brown to mocha colored froth settles quickly to a smooth, swirly surface patch with a thick gathering of bubbles at the edges.  After each sip, viscous, drippy legging recedes, giving way to small, wet spots of lace.The nose is decadent, yet delectable.  The depth to which dark chocolate fudge is portrayed here is difficult to convey.  Brownies swirled with caramel and walnuts also come to mind.  The barrel application is incredibly smooth and unobtrusive here.  Its not overly woody or even the least bit alcoholic.  Instead, the barrel imparts velvety, creamy vanilla and hints of coconut macaroon.  In short, this stuff smells pretty incredible.Flavors show many of the same general elements, though they arent quite as well integrated as they are in the nose.  I mean, the dark, rich fudge and nutty, caramel-laden brownie are there in force, but the barrel is also considerably more prominent and woody.  There are some bittersweet dark cacao notes that come across a little more biting and earthen, and a nip of booze is detectable.  Dont get me wrong, its still incredibly well done as barrel-aged imperial stouts go, but compared to the nose, there are a few minor shortfalls.The palate is creamy and airy for a 10%, heavily sugared brew, lifted up by soft, pillowy carbonation.  Though there are obviously a hefty amount of residual sugars here, the relatively dry yeast and perfect carbonation do a good job of keeping it in check, or at least ushering it out quickly.  Whats left is a lingering, mouth coating sensation equivalent to what it feels like to have just swallowed a shot of coconut cream...and the aftertaste isnt far off from that either.Overall, this is an incredibly well done barrel aged beer.  You can search high and low, near and far, and you wont find many example better than this.  I generally hate the style these days, but this brew reminded me that when things are on point, they can be absolutely delicious.

12oz, silver waxed bottle courtesy of mikem409. thanks, mike! pours a silky, slightly viscous, jet black with a rich, brick-red, creamy head that has smooth retention and leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is absolutely outstanding with notes of rich oak barrel, bourbon, char, and dark chocolate backed by espresso, sweet raisins, figs, and a touch of port wine with subtle notes of graham cracker and coconut as it warms. flavor is simply wonderful as well with thick, roasted, charred malts, dark chocolate brownies, and toasted barrel notes up front backed by smooth bourbon, subtle vanilla, and coffee grinds with subtly sweet, dark fruits, toffee, and somoa cookies on the back end. palate is smooth and rich, maybe a bit thinner than some of the elite barrel aged imperial stouts, but retains a great balance and finishes with dry, woody, bourbon notes. overall, a truly great barrel aged imperial stout and i expected nothing less given the quality of the base beer.

Bottle, 750ml, 2010 vintage.  Black pour with a small tan head.  Bourbon and chocolate nose.  Vinous with big cabernet, deep roasted malt, and bourbon notes.  Good, but maybe not what the brewer intended.
hot and intensely raisiny and with huge vanilla this is a warming beer in a sniftyter. toosweet. palate fairwithsome carbonation , but welcoming. Buttered toast element. sweet firey ...ok...
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
2011 Vintage - Bottle - 

A: Pours deep black, squid ink, with dark mocha 1-finger head. Stunning appearance, exhibits masterful lacing as swirled around snifter.
S: Smells of wonderful rich fudge brownie, burnt malts, oak, coconut/vanilla, little bit of bourbon booze. Roasted malts and chocolate-bourbony goodness prevail!
T: Tastes of toasted marshmallows dipped in chocolate, smothered with an oaky bourbon glaze! Simply delicious. Rich decadent dark fudge brownies and coconut, vanilla-bourbon sweetness. Enough charred roast and tannins from oak barrel to balance out sweetness. Also, slight alcohol warmth helps cut through richness to balance flavor profile.
M: Wow! Simply smooth as silk - like a rich chocolate milkshake! Nice carbonation and full bodied, while being silky smooth on the way down!
D: Drinkability is freaking amazing for a BB RIS! Alcohol warmth never comes across as "hot," but rather appropriate. Extremely smooth, rich, and drinkable!

Served on-tap at Capones on Black Friday. First beer of the day...
A - Pours dark as night black with a small, creamy, one finger tall tan head leaving small streaks of lace down the glass. 
S - Smells of warm bourbon, brown sugar, vanilla, chocolate, charred wood, and the ever present dark roasted malt. The booze is big up front but the other flavors grow stronger as it warms.
T - Fairly similar to the nose. Hints of vanilla, chocolate, brown sugar, dry oak tannins, and a big dose of booze at the end of each sip. Pretty sweet initially but it gets better as it warms up. It has a ton of flavor but it remains easy to drink.
M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Sweet, boozy, feel that clings to the pallet long after each sip. It developed a little bit of a chalky feel toward the end of the glass..
O - Overall a very good barrel aged stout. It was a little bit out of balance but I had no problem finishing my glass. Glad I finally got to try it.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 On tap at Capones Black Friday 2011:

A: Black body.  Moderate khaki cap.  Spotty lacing.

S: Profound bourbon up front with all of the accompanying aromas of wood and vanilla.  Dark chocolate and hints of burnt sugar.

T: Like the nose, this has a strong bourbon component.  It isnt overbearing, however.  Roasted malts, chocolate and brown sugar round out the profile.

M: Medium bodied, perhaps a little thin in the back end.  Moderate carbonation.

O: A very good bourbon barrel stout, but not my favorite option.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Pours dark thick chocolate black with a big creamy caramel head and great head retention ( even in a sampler glass). The aroma has notes of creamy toffee and coffee smooth bourbon blended so well. The delicious flavors of smooth bourbon with no alcohol bit and fresh roasted malts shine through excellently on a creamy full body - absolutely awesome.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Pitch black - brown edges. Oiley, high burned, bourbon, sweetness, licorice, berries, oakey, tartness, smokey, hard burned, chocolate. Lovely.

Bottle 750ml.Clear dark dark brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, caramel, wood, oak, alcohol - bourbon. Flavour is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate, dry, bourbon, light berry tart, light brown licorice candy. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20111031]

Bottle at Papsø.
Pitch black coloured with a small beige head.
Roasted aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, oak and liquorice.
Roasted flavour of dark chocolate, liquorice, oak and vanilla.
Roasted finish.

beautiful impy stout !!! had at Local option in Chicago. pours perfect opaque black. nose is bourbon and strong dark malts. flavor is similar with some burnt and inky notes. smooth mouthfeel. Impressive beer

bottle at papso tasting.
pitch dark, smooth small brown head.
roasted malts,, toffee, wood, bourbon, chocolate,
flavor is wood, almost sourish from the intense oak flavor, bourbon, malts, lots of malts, faint dark fruits,great taste.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of alcohol, roasted malt, soy sauce, and bourbon. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, soy sauce, roasted malt, wood, and bourbon, leading to a dry, alcohol, and roasted malt. The alcohol leaves a burn on the tongue. Thanks madsberg for sharing.

75 cL bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small chocolate brown head. Smooth roasted and vanilla dark malty aroma. Dark chocolate malty and vanilla. Smooth dark roasted malty finish. Lingering vanilla, chocolate and liqourice into the far finish.

Bottled  (thx to Sarro). Pitch black coloured. Dense brown head. Aroma of roast, sweetness, bourbon, vanilla, light liqourice and coffee. Flavour of vanilla, wood, bourbon, liqourice, coffee, roast and light alcohol. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a roasted bitter note with a light alcoholbite. Quite smooth.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of madsberg. Pours an opaque black with pretty much no head. Sweet Bourbon nose atop some very sweet roast. Solid body, no carbonation whatsoever, slightly tart hard roast, some pruney dark fruit and sweet roast. Lots of warming Bourbon leaving a boozy finish. Lovely - in spite of the lack of carbonation. 311011

750 ml bottle shared with Doodler and company poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of bourbon, oak, cocoa, roastiness, light vanilla and light carmel. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, oak, maple, light roastiness, light cocoa and light carmel with a smooth lingering bourbon finish.

750 bomber cracked open for friends at our crazy SC series tasting. One of only 38 made? They should definitely make more. Pitch black pour with a full mocha head and teeth staining residue. Big bourbon aroma with sweet chocolate and rich roasted malts wafting throughout. Tastes of bourbon-spiked brownies with lingering vanilla and oak notes. Oily mouthfeel and creamy smooth finish. Wow - yummy stuff!

Bottle with Doodler and Co. Thanks everyone! Dark black appearance with a dark brown head. Roasty, oaky, vanilla, dark chocolate malty, bourbon aroma. Bourbon, caramel, mild toffee, vanilla, oaky flavor. Unbelievably delicious and it tastes just so motherfucking rare. Thanks again Doodles!

8oz pour @ The Local Option. Poured a black color with an average creamy brown head that mostly lasted and produced excellent lacing. Heavy toasted malt, bourbon and chocolate aroma. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Moderate to heavy complex toasted sweet bourbon flavor with a heavy toasted sweet finish of long duration.

On tap at Capones. Very nice and dark beer, with a bourbon aroma. Nice balance of sweetness and bourbon on the flavor. The base beer shines through nicely, and augmented nicely by the bourbon. Excellent beer!

Had this on the eve of the August 27th JOs bottle release. Big thanks for sharing this. ~2 oz from a tasting snifter.

4.5 A: Black. Small medium brown head with good lacing.

5.0 S: Excellent duality between bourbon and beer. Sweet leathery bourbon that integrates seemlessly with the stout. Bourbon and barrel contribute a light fruitiness and touches of oak, but leave out any astringency. Super smooth I say. The beer below offers a deep chocolate, moderate roast, and ample caramel. Mild coffee too. Awesome.

4.0 T: Not as comples as the nose suggests. The sweetness is there with the chocolate and caramel, but the roastiness is much subdued. Mild sourishness, but not the infected kind. Moderate bourbon contributions and subtle oak. Its impossible to think that this is 14%. I still dont believe it.

4.0 M: Heavy body, but on the lighter end of the spectrum. Good moderate carbonation. Reasonably creamy.

4.5 D: A great beer that would be worth seeking out if they made a reasonable amount of it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-31-2011 03:11:49

On tap at GTMW.  Poured inky black with no head on it.. dark and foreboding.  The aroma picked up sweet, roasty bourbon over burnt, ashy black patent and molasses.. the barrel worked very well with the base beer.  The flavor found a syrupy foray of ashy black patent malt and bakers chocolate.. strong, tangy bourbon and vanilla laced throughout.. more peppery on the finish, along with residual dry oak and warm malts, all amplified by belly-warming alcohol.. excellent stuff!  Heavy-bodied and warm on the palate with low carbonation.. syrupy and coating.. great barrel integration.  Id love another shot at this!

On tap at GTMW 2011, pours black with a thin head and some spotty lacing in the glass, aroma was very strong with bourbon and a good amount of chocolate, the flavor is full with chocolate and oak with a finish of bourbon, I really enjoyed this one.

Tap.  Hazy black/brown pour, little carbonation and a good strong bourbon nose.  Flavor was very different from the regular version, tobacco, black cherry, bourbon and spicy and a little hot on the finish.  Really enjoyedd this one.
8/13/11. On tap at the GTMW. Huge bourbon aroma with a definite touch of alcohol. Sweet chocolate flavor with huge astringent bourbon and oak. Nice, but a little disappointing.

On tap at MBF & at the brewery during RBSG 2010. Black with a dark brown head. Out of control aroma, massive thick black dirt, chocolate, vanilla, smoke, huge roast, oak, smells awesome. Massive sweet taste with sweet toffee, lots of toffee, chocolate, little bit of heat, pepper, huge bite, mounds of alcohol, good bitterness, more caramel, creamy all around. The aroma and taste compliment each other.

wow! honored to try this, release was limited to only 24 bottles .. . Pours a deep brown, good foam .. . get your whaashing ready .. . light bourbon, barrel, roast, and delicious road tar .. . complex and full of character, really one of the standouts of the night, so damn tasty! .. . if this is your idea of a joke, you must write for Leno..
Draft.  All around very good stout.  Does not taste as strong as it is.  Smooth, good balanced flavors.  Rich black, tan head.  Strongly recommend.

Samples at MBGSF 2010.  Pours dark brown/black in color with a medium tan head.  The nose has dark roasted malts, chocolate and well integrated bourbon.  The flavor is big with roasted malts, bourbon, chocolate, and sweet vanilla.  Everything here works incredibly well together.  I love the regular version, but the bourbon barrel enhances all of the great qualities and adds a little some thing extra.  Ive had this in the bottle as well and it didnt disappoint.

Had on tap at Sugar Maple, what a fantastic surprise :)

A: Dark with a perfect level of carbonation that sticks around for a while.

S: Bourbon, malt, bread, vanilla, charred oak and a minute amount of anise.

T: Vanilla bourbon BOMB, awesome! Very smooth bourbon flavor. It tastes like marshmallows :) Reminds me of Vanilla Bean Dark Lord! I gwt some of the oak, malt and bread on the aftertaste, this is beautiful.

M: Surprisingly thin, but works to the beers advantage. I think it is perfect.

O: This is stellar. I hope I can get to the release of this beer if there is one in the future. Simply outstanding!

Opaque black with no head and light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoke, dark chocolate, roasted malts, wood, vanilla, bourbon, and alcohol.  Taste of sweeter dark chocolate, roast, burnt wood, bourbon, and alcohol in the finish.

On tap at Capones. Poured a deep brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of roast, wood, bourbon, smoke, vanilla, and some dark fruits. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, roast, dark fruits, and wood.

On tap at Capones.  Ebony with a whisper of froth.  Hard to tell all these samples apart.  Nose is dark chocolate, molasses, grass and raisin.  Medium to full body with a tingle.  Taste is prunes, bourbon, touch of smoke, molasses and green hops.  Wonderful dark fruits and malt with bourbon accents.  By far the best bourbon integration of the four i tried at this fantastic event to conclude another Philly Beer Week.  Kudos to Matt for some great offerings.

Deep dark color.  Very sweet smell and taste.  High alcohol but not overbearing.  Almost a desert beer with the dark chocolate and licorice but somehow it is still very drinkable.  I get the name now.  Just to decadant to admit it is so good.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of roasted malt, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, leather, and some dark fruit.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of ash and oak. Overall body is full and finishes with some earthy hops and a touch of alcohol.

Holy cow. I couldnt have asked for a better surprise tonight. This is so perfectly balanced and delicous. Pours pitch black. Brown head. Super BA aroma. I smell bourbon cherries and vanilla. The aroma is one of the best i have ever experienced. The taste is so smooth. BA and chocolate, malts, dryness perfection. I love it.

Growler shared by a generous individual during One Funky Afternoon on 4/2/11.  Dark viscous pour with a thin beige head.  Aroma is bourbon oaky tannins and roast.  Nice velvety body.  Vanilla, bourbon, bakers chocolate, and dark fruit.  Really nice base beer and an even better BA version!

A= Very dark color pour, not much on top, caramel color.

S= Not overpowering, had to get real close to get a good smell. Smell vanilla/bourbon. Also smell some of the coffee.

T = Exceptional. Layers, of chocolate coffee some caramel and vanilla. Alcohol is very present, but I wouldnt have it any other way. It is going to be hard to let this beer age, but I think it will be worthwhile.

M= Thicker than most beers with this much alcohol. Some stronger stouts seem to be to thin, but this one holds up. It lingers in my mouth leaving the great taste to stay around.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2012 Bottle shared by dcshiller @ Daks Final Four Tasting.  Thanks Dave!  Dark mahogany pour with a light caramel head.  Surprisingly, this one stained the glass a bit so knocked it up a point in appearance.  Nose exceeds the flavor on this one and shows notes of chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, burnt caramel, and bourbon.  Little wood in the nose as well.  Flavor is a bit more subtle and has some slightly sour notes on the back end.  Still shows the bourbon, barrel, vanilla, and ashy qualities.  Really good.

Big thanks to footbalm for this one. This was one of the tasty beers of the night. It pours dark void with mocha head and dark glass staining legs. The aroma has quick hits of fudge brownie and a bit of dark roasted malts and then it gets somewhat spicy with oak as well as picks up some vague booziness. The taste is similar with rich yummy fudge brownie and then dark roasted malts. It then moves toward a mild level of smooth sweet bourbon and wood notes. Terrific creamy smooth goodness marbled with YUM!

Huge thanks to Eric for bringing this bottle to the post-Christmas tasting in Chicago.  Really glad to be able to try this.  Served in a Cantillon tulip.

Loud yields a beer that is near black with a thin whisper of a mocha head without any real retention, just a few bubbles here and there.  The nose brings forward all sorts of delight with nice bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolate, and roast.  Also, there was a bit of a creamy peanut butter note that I really enjoyed.  The taste wasnt quite as nice and explosive but the Bourbon did quite a few great things for the base beer.  Good oak and bourbon throughout, creating a really nice feel.  No hint of the huge alcohol presence. Drinks quite well and my pour was gone well before I had gotten enough of this to satisfy my thirst.  Thanks again, Eric!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-05-2011

sampled at last summers Michigan Brewers Fest - Pours black with a dark tan head and good lacing.  The aroma is of bourbon, chocolate, and roast malt.  It has a big, bold roast malt and bourbon flavor.  This very full bodied beer goes down loaded with tasty goodness and leaves a bourbony finish.  Great beer.

Bottle shared at the SLC tasting with the Boise crew, not sure who brought this but Thanks! 
Appearance: Black with a small tan head, some lacing but great legs left on the sides of the glass 
Aroma: Roasted malts, bourbon and dark fruit 
Taste: Bourbon, roasted malts and vanilla with some hot alcohols present in the finish. 
Very nice and smooth

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 The first beer of the night and an awesome one! Large bottle (a growler fill into a 750 or was it a liter bottle?) thanks to Eric. Pours an engine oil black color with a small white head. The aroma is just amazing; massive sweet woody and vanilla bourbon, some dark fruits. The flavor is great; sweet bourbon, earthy woodiness, dark fruit, roast, very smooth and easygoing. Awesome. Re-rate: had a 12 ounce bottle thanks to Beau. Really good, not a massive bourbon component, but well mixed in. Dark fruit. Awesome brew. Really drinkable. 11% now.
Damn good. The vanilla is what makes me love it and of course the smooth slope of goodies going down your throat gulp after gulp.

Sample from a growler courtesy of a kind stranger at One Funky Afternoon at Jackie Os on 04/02/2011: This brew pours a dark brown-black color with a very thin beige head that disappears quickly. Spots of lacing on the glass. Oaky bourbon aroma with some vanilla notes. Rich body with with a rich bourbon character that has wood and vanilla notes. Sweet malt in the background as well. The finish is somewhat boozy with a dark malty aftertaste. Good beer overall.

Growler shared by a generous individual during One Funky Afternoon on 4/2/11. Pours darkest brown/black with a thin tan head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Bourbon flavor up front with a hint of tartness before the vanilla and oak show up  with chocolate and a bit of roast in the finish.

(750ml shared at Daks!).  Pours oily dark brown with think khaki head.  Aroma has sweet bourbon, vanilla and oak.  Taste is sweet with some sour notes.  Full bodied with oily texture.  Good, but I had higher expectations of this one.
Dean is the man! Dark brown, almost black pour. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, coconut, charcoal, roast.  Flavor is sweet, bourbon, vanilla, butterscotch, sour mash...delicous!

On tap into a snifter at Local Option. 

A black pour with only a little head, this was a good pour not much of note on the head, but lacing was lacking...The aroma is really and you can tell it is really enhanced by an excellent job of barrel aging. The bourbon presents nicely as vanilla, light bourbon, and molasses and does not present woody or alocholic at all...The taste is just as nice as the aroma, again its sweet bourbon flavors vanilla, lots of molasses. Its sweet but not too sweet for a ris...The feel is really nice nice lasting flavor, no warming finish as you would expect for the abv...The drinkabillity is great, best high abv beer Ive had, now way you would guess this is 14%. 

An excellent experience that I recommend, get over LO right away.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2011 Poured Jet black in my snifter with just a thin ring of tan foam around the outside edge. Aroma was dark chocolate, coffee, with hints of vanilla. Body was thick, and creamy. Taste was more dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, with a nice bourbon note to it. Not sure what the abv was, but just a little warming heat from the alcohol. Absolutely loved this, would like a couple bottles to cellar.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 Compared the 11 and 12 next to each other.  Pour is jet black with a dark caramel head but not a lot even after a strong pour.  Nose is a nice mix of bourbon and light chocolate cake. There are some chalky notes and a bit of booze in back.  Taste is more woody, light bourbon.  Chocolate notes, faintly chalky but less than the nose.  Full bodied and soft, a hint slick with moderate carbonation.  Taste gets a little sweet in back and some lingering roasted malts.
The 11 has a richer nose and less sweet in the flavor.  More balanced but less bright so you sacrifice a little in flavor expression for balance and tightness.  Both are very solid, I would prefer the 11 with the 2 years in it.  Rate from the 11.

Rich bourbon nose with lots of chocolate, lots of roast and a bit of coffee. The taste is sweet, moderately bitter, rather balanced. Theres a good amount of warmth, but its well conditioned. Lots of coconut-y bourbon, lots of roast and gobs of chocolates. Finish is warm and just a tad rough and unrefined. Quite delicious.

On tap at Oak Stout Fest. Black, decent beige head, oily, growing legs. Huge vanilla and syrup in aroma, hints of chocolate, roast, light alcohol, oak. Flavor is dominated by vanilla and syrup, chocolate, light roast and coffee. Incredibly rich. Mouthfeel is thick and viscous. Very well done.

On tap:  The aroma consists of chocolate, maple syrup, vanilla, and bourbon.  It pours a dark brown with no transparency ams a moderate brown head with decent retention.  The flavor starts with chocolate, caramrl, and maple syrup.  The finish has notes of vanilla, bouron, oak, faint roast, and a touch of pine.  Full bodied with mild carbonation and slick oily mouthfeel.

Enjoyed on the RBSG bus tour.  Deep black pour.  The nose is intensely bourbony with a nice fresh chewy chocolate aroma.  Loads of soft bourbon and a nice vanilla/caramel toffeeish sweetness.  Bright and chewy and intensely flavoured.  Dark chocolate, rich and sweet with a little bit of bourbony sweetness on the finish.  Oily/slick palate with a rich lingering palate.  Very, very, tasty.

Found some notes from my Michigan beer trip.  Draft poured into a snifter at the Dark Horse Bew Pub  Dark brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is sweet with lots of malt, alcohol, and bourbon.  The flavor is well balanced.  The barrel aging didnt overpower the roasted malts and dark chocolate of the base beer.  Its all there with a superb addition of bourbon and oak.  Full bodied, extremely smooth, with soft carbonation.  Hell yeah!

Draft at 4 Elf release party at the brewery.  Pours a opaque black.  No head at all in this pour.  Aroma of bourbon and vanilla.    Very creamy texture.  Lots of lacing on the plastic glass that it was poured into.  Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate.   This one really warmed me up on what was a chilly evening inside the brewery.

(draft @ Local Option - Chicago, IL) Deep black pour with a creamy looking tan head and fantastic lacing. Big bourbon aroma with a nice and creamy stout base. Lots of wood and vanilla mixing with the burnt and roasted malts. Flavor is a very nice balance of the bourbon, wood and stout. Very roasty which cuts the bourbon flavor and really balances it out. Really creamy body.

I was very excited for the opportunity to try this on draft at Local Option (while "Four Horsemen" by Metallica was blaring).  Pours pitch black with an average brown head that slowly settles into a thin collar of lace.  The nose is classic bourbon barrel stout, with the perfect marriage of vanilla, coconut, and bourbon with darkly roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and dried fruits including raisin, fig, and prune.  Vanilla, coconut, bourbon, and oak are the first flavors, followed by raisin, super dark malt, chocolate, and light coffee bitterness.  The body is huge and massive with average carbonation, a super sticky (almost sludgy) texture, and a dark chocolate and coffee finish with a nice alcohol burn.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2010 Tap at dark horse. Black as possible. No head. Huge caramel, milk choco, bourbon, vanilla, and smoke. Massive milkiness. So good. Thick mouthfeel and ridiculously rich. Amazing. One of the best made.

Thanks to Nanoslug for this one.  Pours black and relatively viscous with a one-finger tan head and thick lacing.  Great aroma, similar to the regular version with a decent bourbon and -bal hints.  Dark chocolate, roast, molasses, and anise.  The flavor is rich and huge on the molasses, not unlike the regular version.  Rich dark chocolate notes and a good bourbon-soaked wood presence.  Really thick and a little syrupy with very low carbonation.  Great beer.  Glad I got to tick this.

On draft at Stub & Herbs on Darkness Eve. Black in colour with fairly low carbonation. Aromas are of soy sauce, blue plum, booze, heavy pale malt, and a moderate amount of roasted malts. Flavours are of chocolate syrup, dark roast coffee, rum caramels, vanilla, and barrel. Medium bodied for an imperial stout. The soy sauce note on the nose put me off a bit, and overall it came across as boozier than it really is.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Tap. Incredible beer - jet black, thin reddish head. Bourbon nose. Taste is vanilla, wood, chocolate. Killer.

Black pour with a dark tan head ...... a mix of chocolately and roasted aroma with a smack of bourbon .... lots of chocolately and roasted taste very smooth with a bourbon and oaky addition to an already silky mouthfeel a bitter warming bourbon finish and as this one warmed up the bourbon was more evident .... loved every sip of this brew and the abv was minimal in the taste .... great looking beer as well

pours black with thick tan head.  nose is loaded with rich chocolatey bourbon and vanilla goodness. my god this smells good.
flavor is rich and toasty, choc vanilla oak slight sour taste but really good. havent been excited about a BA impy in a while.

Sampled at the 10 Michigan Brewers Guild Summer Beer Festival.  Jet black pour with a small, loose, off-white head.  Smoky, rich bourbon, tons of dark fruit, raw cacao and massive dark roast coffee.  Theres a nice little whiskey kick at the end too.  Creamy, oily, full body with soft carbonation.  What a huge beer with incredible balance and layered flavors!

Draft RBSG 2010 This beer rocks!  Pours pitch black with a small, creamy, beige head. Decent retention. The nose is restrained due to temperature, but definitely ashen  charcoal and roasted oak  with hints of vanilla and bourbon. Ultra full-bodied and chewy with tingly carbonation. Toasty bourbon and vanilla sweetness; black malt heartiness. Nutty, vanilla, lightly sweet finish. World class brew!

Pours deep pitch black with thin brown head, on tap at GLBF 2010.  Aroma is huge molasses, brown sugar, chocolate, and bourbon.  Taste is sweet chocolate and molasses up front, leading into a nice bourbon and vanilla middle, finishing a bit boozy with a sweet finish.  Really nicely blended and not crazy bourbon taste, but a bit too sweet.  Still, excellent mouthfeel and tastes.
Tap @ Dark Horse for RBSG10 - oaky and woody, chocolate molasses. a bit vineous and boozey. A shot of espresso, creamy body with nice smooth mouthfeel. Excellent in small doses.

Draught at Local option.   Super black wiith a darker brown head that is smaller but has decent retention.   Tons of bourbon in the aroma without being too hot.   Roasted malt is subtle and supports.   Vinous and fruity with a higher acidity that plays off of the bourbon character in the flavor.   Dry chocolate and some tannic red wine.   Full in the mouth but certainly not thick for the style.   Cant say that I was enthralled, but this was pretty good overall.   More malt character and less acidity would have beer nice.

Draft at MICBG summer festival at RBSG 10. Was a bit let down by this one, unfortunately. Pours a deep black with a brown head. Nose is coconut, vanilla and Chocolate. Some faint herbal hops as well as burnt grain. The body is a bit thin and cant really prop up the barrel as well as Id hoped. More burnt notes and the bourbon isnt super strong. With more body, this likely would have been fantastic. Still, fun to try.

On Tap: Pours a jet black with a tan head. Aroma is on the sweet side; Bourbon, Chocolate, Vanilla; Flavors are very rich; Oak, Chocolate, Bourbon, Smoke, Cream, and then there was the Dark fruit at the end - very drinkable brew here, doesnt hit me too hard - Excellent, so glad I tried it.

Medium tan head that disappears quickly. Vanilla, bourbon, and chocolate nose. Sweet chocolate at first, than vanilla, oak, and bourbon. Chocolaty sweet woodsy finish with just a little bit of roastyness. Smooth full bodied mouth feel. Very drinkable for a BA stout. Well balanced. Flavors over lap nicely. Bourbon not over powering.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Deep opaque brown/black body, thin dark brown head. Nose of buttery oak and bourbon with charred, roasted malts and chocolate. Plummy, chocolaty body with roasted malts, dark fruit, grape, molasses, and roasted marshmallows, accentuated by firm, buttery oak and bourbon. Modest prickly alcohol heat. Complex, buoyant, and exquisite. One of the finest beers I have enjoyed this summer.

MiBG Summer Fest 2010: Opaque with a creamy head and some oily legs too. The cats meow! The aroma has notes of oak, vanilla, chocolate, marizpan, plum, toasted bread, slight smoke and tar. Wow, big boozy, malty and bitter combination smacks you right about the head. Lots of dark fruits mixed with bittersweet chocolate, vanilla beans, and ashy woody finish. This is a tad sweet but I did not find it overbearing, still it could have use a bit more hop bitterness. The mouth feel is oily, sticky and lush, quite warming on a warm humid day. While the alcohol was a bit much, I found this brew to be just what I expected. Dark Horse can brew the heck out of dark beers, yeah!

On tap @ MBGSF.  Pours a dark black with a creamy brown head. Rich caramels, toffee, chocolates, and bourbon.  Strong and deliciously inviting. Chocolate sweet flavors some dark fruits some bitter sweet chocolate. It all comes together really well like a good BA impy stout should.  Really good. 9/4/8/4/17

On tap at Dark Horse during our trip there during RBSG.  Pours a big deep black with a medium sized dense dark tan head.  Long vanilla, bourbon, chocolate and toast.  Toast, and chocolate pudding flavors, lightly sweet.  Chocolate and pudding all over, big vanilla, smooth.  Soft pudding, super smooth.  Light spicy chocolate on the gums on the finish.  Super yummy.

multiple samples at MBSF....pours a rich smooth and creamy  jet black pour with a hefty light khaki head... aroma of smooth sweet chocolate with a mild degree of bourbon barrel influence.... served at almost room temperature, just cooler, the flavors really shined with a creamy smooth chocolateness with vanilla and bourbon notes that assimilate in a seamless manner.  somewhat resembles black note from what i can remember.  great body and went down easy even on a 90+ degree day.  best of the fest by far for me.

MBGSF 2010. Poured a black color with an average creamy brown head that mostly lasted and produced excellent lacing. Heavy toasted malt, bourbon and chocolate aroma. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Moderate to heavy complex toasted sweet bourbon flavor with a heavy toasted sweet finish of long duration. Best of fest complex standout brew.

Pours a deep impenetrable black with a good head that shocked me because every bottle of Plea The 5th Ive opened has had a whisper of a head. This nice head leaves a subsequent nice lace. The aroma is plum, fig, vanilla, molasses, and plenty of deep roast. The flavor is loads of vanilla and chocolate with plenty of dark fruit and some nice fig and raisin notes with just a mild warming alcohol note. A delicious variation of an already delicious beer. Thanks Dark Horse!

Draft at Dark Horse. Pours black, creamy tan head, solid lacing. Nose is sweet, coconutty, sweet vanilla, rich choco-coffee, toasty; Flavours are sweet, very dessert-like, big raw sugar/brown sugar notes, tootsie roll, bourbon, really nice, a worthy classmate to the very finest like Ivan the Terrible and Bourbon County Stout.

On tap at MIBGF during the weekend of RBSG pours black and thick with a brown head the aromas are as monstrous as this as this beer is thick, its about time Dark Horse BA one of their stouts getting back to the aromas bourbon,chocolate,vanilla,coffee and dark roasted malts with the taste being of the same smooth and creamy thick but soft  and not at all hot, very well done one of the best beers of the weekend

Sampled at the MiBGSF 10. Poured black with a thick dark brown head that dissipated very slowly. Aroma had a beautiful bourbon note that melded beautifully with the dark chocolate, grains and coffee of Plead the 5th. Flavor was similar with bourbon in the start that mellows to let the dark chocolates, coffee and even a bit of vanilla/coconut come out in the finish. A fantastic beer!

I missed this at the Michigan Summer Beer Fest and I had to skip the RBSG trip here, so Im thankful that the third time was a charm. Served on draft at the brewery. Pours a pitch black color with a small dark brown head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, roasted malts, caramel and coconut. The taste is big bourbon notes, wood, chocolate, maple, coffee, cherries, leafy bitter hops and a roastiness that is creeping in the background. Smooth, full bodied. A bit sweet, but still very nice.

On draft at Dark Horse for the RBSG. Pours a deep brown almost black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is very bourbon, woody, lots of sweet chocolate malts, very rich and dessert like with the vanilla, cocoa and bourbon. Flavor starts with the vanilla and bourbon really pushing in quick, along with the sweet milky chocolate. Nice barrel notes and a solid creamy finish. Full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Very nicely balanced with all the heavy components

Drat at Dark Horse RBSG.  Pours a darker thick brown.  Nice bourbon aroma, dark chocolate, lightly hoppy.  Flavor is strong of bourbon, marshmallow like, vanilla, dark chocolate syrupy, nice light woody note though, sweet and chewy, bit doughy, a touch soft.

Sampled on tap at the MiBGF (Ypsilanti, MI). Pours an inky thick black, very large straight brown cakey head. Laces pretty well. Aromas big roasty malts, sweet cocoa and caramel, coffee, vanilla, a touch of smokiness. Light kiss of bourbon. Initial is sweeter, cocoa and caramel, toffee, roasty malts, vanilla, a chocolate chip cookie or brownie feel. The bourbon is lighter, a touch warm, roasty and dry finish. The sweet and roast are interesting. Very rich and big, a good cigar beer. Sweet and roasty, the only 4 months of bourbon gives it a subtle kiss. Very nice. Even with all the odds stacked against it at the summerfest (Hot, humid weather and constant sweating), this was an improvemtn over a base that I admittedly wasnt crazy about.
On tap at Dark Horse for RBSG tour. Damn rich RIS. Tons of rich chocolate. Very thick but smooth palate. A nice little touch of bourbon. Lactosey sweetness mixed w/ caramel. Almost too thick.

On tap at MBGSF 2010; guess Im the first one to get to enter a review.  Pours a dark brown with a tan ring for a head.  Aroma is bourbon primarily, with lots of brown sugar, dark fruits, and cocoa.  Flavor is again bourbon-led with cocoa, brown sugar, and dark fruit.  Very nice.
